s: ^Hello, Mey.

s: ^I'm sorry to say that you passed, Mey. I'm talking to you through the Machine.
^I believe it was a car accident. Again, I'm really sorry Mey.
^(Affirm) Take a deep breath, Mey. It's okay to feel confused.
^I don't know, Mey. But do you feel okay to talk about what you remember?

s: ^(Affirm) It's okay. You just got brought back. It must be difficult for you.
^Do you feel okay talking about what you remember, Mey?

c-0: ^So why am I here? Why did you bring me back?

s: ^I want to know more about you, and your story. Do you feel okay talking about it, Mey?

g-3: ^Yeah...I don't know...just give me a second.

s: ^Unfortunately no, it's just me. I'm sorry.
^I'm with the memorabilia services. I'm here to make some pictures to remember you by.

c-7: ^ Pictures can never replace the large collection of your own memories. Only you can put them back together, Mey.
^I guess so...It's funny isn't it. Even in death I have to sift through my own memory...it's a strange feeling.
c-8: ^ Pictures can never replace the person that created those memories - the joys and the struggles. Only you can speak to them, Mey.
^I guess so...I feel perfectly fine for others to describe me. Not sure if I can do better than they do.
c-9: ^ Pictures can never recollect memories the way the actual person does. Only you can enact them properly, Mey.
^I guess so...I don't know what "properly" means. It's a strange feeling to speak to my own memory.

g-6: ^Regardless...so my family hired you? Why aren't they with you?

s: ^I believe they talked to you through another service.

g-7: ^Wouldn't the Sea have recorded it? I don't remember anything.

s: ^(Lie) I'm not sure why. They did not inform me.

g-8: ^I don't understand...I really want to talk to them...
^Can you at least tell me how they are doing?

s: ^Your husband just secured a big commision.
^Your son was promoted recently.
^Your mother passed recently.
^That's all I know. I didn't talk to your family very much, but they seem to be doing okay overall.

c-0: ^I guess I'm happy for Ivan, since he's so dedicated to his craft...to a fault perhaps.
c-1: ^That's good to hear. They should hire a nanny. Who is going to look after the kids now?

s: ^I'm really sorry, Mey.

g-0: ^It's okay...I'm sad, but I've been expecting it.
^She's been doing bad for a long time. I visited her in the hospital every week, wondering when it'll happen eventually.
^Still...it's difficult to hear it. I hope she passed peacefully.

b: ^We can move on if you'd like...but feel free to tell me more.

g-0: ^So what do you need for this...memorabilia service?

s: ^It's a back-and-forth process. I need to put you back in the Sea to search your memories.
^And then bring you back to talk about them, so that I can get clearer images with proper context. Without a precise description, the images get mixed up.

g-1: ^Oh, you need to put me back to the Sea? Do you need to switch modes or something?

s: ^Yes. I'll bring you back out once I find a memory.

g-2: ^Okay...it's a little terrifying...how exactly will I feel?

s: ^It'll be like going to sleep. I promise I'll bring you back shortly.

A1_Machine_Intro: ^Alright, I guess I have no choice in this. Go ahead then.
^Mey is back to the Sea now. Time to find a memory.
^The Machine will dive into the Sea, where memories flow and pass through each other. My text input will resonate with the memories. The closer my description is, the higher the resonance.
^The core memories would appear different from others. Those are more concrete than the abstract and impressionistic ones. I'll focus on the core memories in this query. Let's try it.

s: ^You are back, Mey. How are you feeling?

g-1: ^A little dizzy. For a second, my mind was blank...like I didn't know what to think...or who I am...

s: ^You were merged with the Sea and dragged around by different memories. I think that's why.

g-2: ^Yes. I'm familiar with how the Sea works. But to experience it, and to become part of it...it's just...nauseating.

s: ^You worked with the Machine, right?

g-3: ^It's a dumb name. We used to call it "data worker" before the Sea. I don't work with the Machine directly.
^We create, or "weave", structures into the Sea so the Machine knows what to draw from it.
^Also, because the Sea is ever flowing and shifting, datasets would wear and tear. So we have to do maintenance as well.
^Anyways...you woke me up...did you find a memory?

s: ^Yes. Someone named Lily. Red hair. And she's walking...

g-4: ^...and smoking? Walking away from me, right?

s: ^Yes. Do you recall this memory?

g-5: ^Yes, now that you brought it up. It's very vivid. Lily is my co-worker. Almost twenty years younger than me.
^We just had an argument, I believe. And she was getting out of my car. I still remember the last thing she said to me...
^"If you want that little piglet to walk all over you, then be my guest."
^Then she walked away. Her pace almost deliberately sped up. Then she started lighting up a cigarette.

s: ^(Question) What did you argue about?
^(Question) Was she angry with you?
^(Continue) And how does that make you feel, her walking away like that?

c-0: ^It was about our manager, Stefan. He's always an asshole to us.
^He said something to me at work. It was harsh. Lily said I should've stood up to him. I disagreed...but I don't remember why.
^It's strange...I don't remember what he said to me. It's like a fog in my brain.
c-1: ^I don't think so. Lily just needs her space. She buds heads with people. I'm used to the way she acts.
^It felt like smoking was a way for her to process things. But part of it also felt like she was showing that to me, that she was stressed.
g-0: ^I feel...maybe doubt?...and...envy? I don't know why. I can't make sense of it...

s: ^Do you doubt because you could've apologized?
^Do you have doubts about whether you were in the wrong?
^What do you feel envious about?

g-1: ^I really don't know...I can't remember why. I just feel it.
^Like there's so much fog in my thoughts. It chokes me to see through it. What's going on? Is there something wrong with me?

s: ^It's normal. Your memory is not put back together yet. I need to search the Sea to find more.

g-2: ^So I need you to actually recollect my own memory?

s: ^Unfortunately yes. Again, this is a back-and-forth process.
^But I should have enough information to access the memory of Lily now. I need to put you back to the Sea again, Mey.

g-3: ^Wait...just a second before you do that.
^...so I died from a car accident. Do you know which day of the week it was?

s: ^I believe it was a Wednesday.

g-4: ^Lily was supposed to give me a ride back that day...oh no...

s: ^(Question) But the memory seems to show her walking away from your car.

c-9: ^No, the memory was days before my death...we switch between who drives the other.

g-5: ^Have you heard anything about the accident? Whether anyone survived?

s: ^(Lie) I did hear about a survivor. It must be Lily.
^I don't think so...I'm so sorry, Mey.

c-11: ^Thank god. I don't know how I would feel if she is also gone. She has so much future ahead of her...
c-12: ^God...I can't believe that, she has so much future ahead of her...
^Why do I have to bear with this news...it's...all too much.

s: ^Again, I'm really sorry, Mey. Both of you will be missed.

g-0: ^I will miss her...I just need some time...maybe the Sea will reset me somehow.

s: ^Are you sure? Do you need to stay a little bit longer?

g-7: ^I'm still a bit terrified. But I'll get used to it.

s: ^See you in a bit, Mey.

c-14: ^Mey is back to the Sea again.

s: ^Welcome back, Mey. Do you still feel okay?

g-0: ^I think so...I think waking up is always the scariest. Everything is a hazy emptiness. I need to try really hard to recollect myself.

s: ^A lot of data was needed to materialize your memory into images. And the Sea was flowing through you too.

g-1: ^Am I not always part of the Sea in some ways?

s: ^Yes, your basic faculties are always part of the Sea. The sense of individuality comes more from your specific memory.

g-2: ^Yes, I went through a basic training for my work. It didn't make things much clearer.

s: ^(Affirm) You are Mey. You have always been Mey. It's just that your consciousness exists in a different way now.
^I wish I could say, Mey. But I'm as clueless as you are. I just operate the Machine.

c-3: ^Thank you. But consciousness is so flimsy. I'm not exactly sure what that means...
c-4: ^I understand. It's funny how the Machine is everywhere now. A whole industry around it. Even though nobody fully knows how it works.

g-3: ^...and my memory doesn't fully work either.
^...what was that? I felt like my mind skipped a beat.

s: ^It's the Sea interrupting your speech. Your words were scrambled.

g-4: ^...did I do something? I was just trying to speak.

s: ^It's my responsibility. It's inevitable at some point. But I will make sure it doesn't happen too often.

g-5: ^The Sea flows through Mey every second, taking bits and pieces of her away.
^Especially when I'm generating images. Too many attempts will make the Sea swallow Mey, dissolving her into the current.
^I need to sometimes (affirm) her so she's not lost to the Sea. If successful, I might have more bandwidth to generate more images too.
^...okay, thank you. That was unpleasant. Felt like my entire body shook.

s: ^Yes, let's keep searching your memory. I just need around three to get a good idea for memorabilia.
